column4: Hey now that i have ubuntu, i have no idea what to do with it......how am i supposed to attain unix mastery when i dont even know what that is.....any help, advice, support, guidance, cheese burgers?
Lots of good books
You could get the Ubuntu Pocket Guide, a PDF is available for free at www.ubuntupocketguide.com/download_main.html
Depending on what you want, something like The Practical Guide to Ubuntu Linux may not be a bad idea, or a book on Linux in general, or another related subject you're interested in
Not to mention you can program from any text editor out of the box, and then use a built in free compiler to put it together
It is a different environment, I find unix to be much more logical and easy to work with
You might see if your library has a Linux book. Some of the specifics may be different but the general overview of what it is, what you can accomplish, and why you would use it will be the same
Practice using it :) Learn by baby steps. Ubuntu has very good documentation
For a good start, other than the book link I sent you, consider https://help.ubuntu.com/9.04/index.html
Chances are you don't even need to
Through the add/remove programs or package manager, or from a website?
It's in the repositories, you don't have to (and it's not suggested you do so)
Open Applications > Add/Remove..., change the pull down to All Available Applications and search for Xchat
What did it say?
You use pppoe? Are you connected to a router or directly to the modem?
Have you tried configuring the connection using network manager? (the network icon in the top)
No way to configure a connection in there?
Actually, you should be able to do it with network manager
This is a DSL connection?
Are you booted into Ubuntu on that machine?
You should be able to right click the network icon, choose Edit Connections, and click DSL and click add
And nothing?
You can format your drive in the installer and install over it, yes
You can choose the partitions you put Ubuntu on, put it on the old Ubuntu one and don't touch the Windows one
